name: aws-network-firewall
label: AWS Network Firewall
description: AWS Network Firewall is a managed service that makes it easy to deploy essential network protections for all of your Amazon Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs). Network Firewall is a stateful, managed, network firewall and intrusion detection and prevention service. This Connector automated operations such as retrieving create, update and delete operation in AWS Network firewall.

fields.title: Configuration Type
fields.name: config_type
fields.description: Select configuration type that is how you want to provide credentials.

IAM Role.title: AWS Instance IAM Role
IAM Role.name: aws_iam_role
IAM Role.tooltip: IAM Role of your AWS instance to access AWS services.
IAM Role.description: IAM Role of your AWS instance to access AWS services.

Access Credentials.title: AWS Region
Access Credentials.name: aws_region
Access Credentials.tooltip: Your account's AWS region that you will use to access AWS services.
Access Credentials.description: Your account's AWS region that you will use to access AWS services.

Access Credentials.title: AWS Access Key ID
Access Credentials.name: aws_access_key
Access Credentials.tooltip: ID of the AWS Access Key to access AWS services.

Access Credentials.title: AWS Secret Access Key
Access Credentials.name: aws_secret_access_key
Access Credentials.tooltip: Key of the AWS Secret Access to access AWS services.
Access Credentials.description: Key of the AWS Secret Access to access AWS services.

operations.title: Get Associate Firewall Policy
operations.description: Get associates a FirewallPolicy to a Firewall. A firewall policy defines how to monitor and manage your VPC network traffic, using a collection of inspection rule groups and other settings. Each firewall requires one firewall policy association, and you can use the same firewall policy for multiple firewalls.

parameters.title: Assume a Role
parameters.name: assume_role
parameters.tooltip: Enable to assume a role
parameters.description: Select this option to assume a role.Note: You must enable this option, i.e., this parameter is required, if you have specified IAM Role as the 'Configuration Type'. If you have specified Access Credentials as the 'Configuration Type', then this parameter is optional.If you select this option, i.e., set it to 'True' then you must specify the following parameters: AWS Region: AWS region of your account to access the AWS AWS Route 53. Role ARN: ARN of the role that you want to assume to execute this action on AWS.Session Name: Name of the session that will be created to execute this action on AWS.

true.title: AWS Region
true.name: aws_region
true.tooltip: Your account's AWS region that you will use to access AWS services.
true.description: Your account's AWS region that you will use to access AWS services.

true.title: Role ARN
true.name: role_arn
true.tooltip: ARN of the role that you want assume to execute this action on AWS.
true.description: ARN of the role that you want assume to execute this action on AWS.

true.description: Name of the session that will be created to execute this action on AWS.

parameters.title: Firewall Policy ARN
parameters.name: FirewallPolicyArn
parameters.tooltip: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the firewall policy.
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the firewall policy.

parameters.title: Firewall ARN
parameters.name: FirewallArn
parameters.tooltip: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the firewall. You must specify the ARN or the name, and you can specify both.
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the firewall. You must specify the ARN or the name, and you can specify both.

parameters.title: Firewall Name
parameters.name: FirewallName
parameters.tooltip: The descriptive name of the firewall. You can't change the name of a firewall after you create it. You must specify the ARN or the name, and you can specify both.
parameters.description: The descriptive name of the firewall. You can't change the name of a firewall after you create it. You must specify the ARN or the name, and you can specify both.

parameters.title: Update Token
parameters.name: UpdateToken
parameters.tooltip: An optional token that you can use for optimistic locking. Network Firewall returns a token to your requests that access the firewall. The token marks the state of the firewall resource at the time of the request.
parameters.description: An optional token that you can use for optimistic locking. Network Firewall returns a token to your requests that access the firewall. The token marks the state of the firewall resource at the time of the request.

operations.title: Get Associate Subnets
operations.description: Associates the specified subnets in the Amazon VPC to the firewall. You can specify one subnet for each of the Availability Zones that the VPC spans. This request creates an AWS Network Firewall firewall endpoint in each of the subnets. To enable the firewall's protections, you must also modify the VPC's route tables for each subnet's Availability Zone, to redirect the traffic that's coming into and going out of the zone through the firewall endpoint.

If you select this option, i.e., set it to 'True' then you must specify the following parameters:

parameters.title: Limit
parameters.name: MaxResults
parameters.tooltip: The maximum number of objects that you want Network Firewall to return for this request.
parameters.description: The maximum number of objects that you want Network Firewall to return for this request.

parameters.title: Next Token
parameters.name: NextToken
parameters.tooltip: When you request a list of objects with a MaxResults setting, if the number of objects that are still available for retrieval exceeds the maximum you requested, Network Firewall returns a NextToken value in the response. To retrieve the next batch of objects, use the token returned from the prior request in your next request.
parameters.description: When you request a list of objects with a MaxResults setting, if the number of objects that are still available for retrieval exceeds the maximum you requested, Network Firewall returns a NextToken value in the response. To retrieve the next batch of objects, use the token returned from the prior request in your next request.

operations.title: Create Firewall
operations.description: Creates an AWS Network Firewall Firewall and accompanying Firewall Status for a VPC. The firewall defines the configuration settings for an AWS Network Firewall firewall. The settings that you can define at creation include the firewall policy, the subnets in your VPC to use for the firewall endpoints, and any tags that are attached to the firewall AWS resource.

parameters.title: Assume a Role
parameters.name: assume_role
parameters.tooltip: Enable to assume a role
parameters.description: Select this option to assume a role.Note: You must enable this option, i.e., this parameter is required, if you have specified IAM Role as the 'Configuration Type'. If you have specified Access Credentials as the 'Configuration Type', then this parameter is optional.If you select this option, i.e., set it to 'True' then you must specify the following parameters: AWS Region: AWS region of your account to access the AWS AWS Route 53. Role ARN: ARN of the role that you want to assume to execute this action on AWS.Session Name: Name of the session that will be created to execute this action on AWS.

true.title: AWS Region
true.name: aws_region
true.tooltip: Your account's AWS region that you will use to access AWS services.
true.description: Your account's AWS region that you will use to access AWS services.

true.title: Role ARN
true.name: role_arn
true.tooltip: ARN of the role that you want assume to execute this action on AWS.
true.description: ARN of the role that you want assume to execute this action on AWS.

true.title: Session Name
true.name: session_name

true.description: Name of the session that will be created to execute this action on AWS.

parameters.title: Firewall Name
parameters.name: FirewallName
parameters.description: The descriptive name of the firewall. You can't change the name of a firewall after you create it.

parameters.title: Firewall Policy ARN
parameters.name: FirewallPolicyArn
parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the FirewallPolicy that you want to use for the firewall.

parameters.title: Description
parameters.name: Description
parameters.description: A description of the firewall.

parameters.title: Delete Protection
parameters.name: DeleteProtection
parameters.tooltip: A flag indicating whether it is possible to delete the firewall. A setting of TRUE indicates that the firewall is protected against deletion. Use this setting to protect against accidentally deleting a firewall that is in use. When you create a firewall, the operation initializes this flag to TRUE.
parameters.description: A flag indicating whether it is possible to delete the firewall. A setting of TRUE indicates that the firewall is protected against deletion. Use this setting to protect against accidentally deleting a firewall that is in use. When you create a firewall, the operation initializes this flag to TRUE.

parameters.title: Firewall Policy Change Protection
parameters.name: FirewallPolicyChangeProtection
parameters.description: A setting indicating whether the firewall is protected against a change to the firewall policy association. Use this setting to protect against accidentally modifying the firewall policy for a firewall that is in use. When you create a firewall, the operation initializes this setting to TRUE.
parameters.tooltip: A setting indicating whether the firewall is protected against a change to the firewall policy association. Use this setting to protect against accidentally modifying the firewall policy for a firewall that is in use. When you create a firewall, the operation initializes this setting to TRUE.

parameters.title: Subnet Change Protection
parameters.name: SubnetChangeProtection
parameters.description: A setting indicating whether the firewall is protected against changes to the subnet associations. Use this setting to protect against accidentally modifying the subnet associations for a firewall that is in use. When you create a firewall, the operation initializes this setting to TRUE.
parameters.tooltip: A setting indicating whether the firewall is protected against changes to the subnet associations. Use this setting to protect against accidentally modifying the subnet associations for a firewall that is in use. When you create a firewall, the operation initializes this setting to TRUE.

parameters.title: SubnetIDs
parameters.name: SubnetMappings
parameters.tooltip: The IDs of the subnets that you want to associate with the firewall. The public subnets to use for your Network Firewall firewalls. Each subnet must belong to a different Availability Zone in the VPC. Network Firewall creates a firewall endpoint in each subnet.
parameters.description: The IDs of the subnets that you want to associate with the firewall. The public subnets to use for your Network Firewall firewalls. Each subnet must belong to a different Availability Zone in the VPC. Network Firewall creates a firewall endpoint in each subnet.

parameters.title: VPC ID
parameters.name: VpcId
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the VPC where Network Firewall should create the firewall.
parameters.tooltip: The unique identifier of the VPC where Network Firewall should create the firewall.

parameters.title: Tags
parameters.name: Tags
parameters.description: CSV list of the tags (key:value pairs) to associate with the resource. Notes Array Members: Minimum number of 1 item. Maximum number of 200 items.
parameters.tooltip: CSV list of the tags (key:value pairs) to associate with the resource. Notes Array Members: Minimum number of 1 item. Maximum number of 200 items.

operations.title: Create Firewall Policy
operations.description: Creates the firewall policy for the firewall according to the specifications. An AWS Network Firewall firewall policy defines the behavior of a firewall, in a collection of stateless and stateful rule groups and other settings. You can use one firewall policy for multiple firewalls.

parameters.title: Assume a Role
parameters.name: assume_role
parameters.tooltip: Enable to assume a role
parameters.description: Select this option to assume a role.Note: You must enable this option, i.e., this parameter is required, if you have specified IAM Role as the 'Configuration Type'. If you have specified Access Credentials as the 'Configuration Type', then this parameter is optional.If you select this option, i.e., set it to 'True' then you must specify the following parameters: AWS Region: AWS region of your account to access the AWS AWS Route 53. Role ARN: ARN of the role that you want to assume to execute this action on AWS.Session Name: Name of the session that will be created to execute this action on AWS.

parameters.title: Firewall Policy Name
parameters.name: FirewallPolicyName

parameters.title: Firewall Policy
parameters.name: firewall_policy_json
parameters.tooltip: JSON string of the rule groups and policy actions to use in the firewall policy.
parameters.description: JSON string of the rule groups and policy actions to use in the firewall policy.

parameters.title: Description
parameters.name: Description
parameters.description: A description of the firewall policy.

parameters.title: Tags
parameters.name: Tags
parameters.description: CSV list of the tags (key:value pairs) to associate with the resource. The key:value pair can be anything you define. Typically, the tag key represents a category (such as "environment") and the tag value represents a specific value within that category (such as "test," "development," or "production"). You can add up to 50 tags to each AWS resource.
parameters.tooltip: CSV list of the tags (key:value pairs) to associate with the resource. The key:value pair can be anything you define. Typically, the tag key represents a category (such as "environment") and the tag value represents a specific value within that category (such as "test," "development," or "production"). You can add up to 50 tags to each AWS resource.

operations.title: Create Rule Group
operations.description: Creates the specified stateless or stateful rule group, which includes the rules for network traffic inspection, a capacity setting, and tags.

parameters.title: Assume a Role
parameters.name: assume_role
parameters.tooltip: Enable to assume a role
parameters.description: Select this option to assume a role.Note: You must enable this option, i.e., this parameter is required, if you have specified IAM Role as the 'Configuration Type'. If you have specified Access Credentials as the 'Configuration Type', then this parameter is optional.If you select this option, i.e., set it to 'True' then you must specify the following parameters: AWS Region: AWS region of your account to access the AWS AWS Route 53. Role ARN: ARN of the role that you want to assume to execute this action on AWS.Session Name: Name of the session that will be created to execute this action on AWS.

true.tooltip: Your account's AWS region that you will use to access AWS services.

parameters.title: Rule Group Name
parameters.name: rule_group_name
parameters.tooltip: Indicates whether the rule group is stateless or stateful. If the rule group is stateless, it contains stateless rules. If it is stateful, it contains stateful rules. Possible values are: STATELESS, STATEFUL
parameters.description: Indicates whether the rule group is stateless or stateful. If the rule group is stateless, it contains stateless rules. If it is stateful, it contains stateful rules. Possible values are: STATELESS, STATEFUL

parameters.title: Setting Type
parameters.name: setting_type
parameters.tooltip: Provide either Rule Group Setting or a Rules Setting. If you choose "Rule Group Setting", then you must specify the JSON object that defines the rule group rules. If you choose "Rules Setting", then you need to provide a string containing stateful rule group rules specifications in Suricata flat format, with one rule per line. Use this to import your existing Suricata compatible rule groups.
parameters.description: Enable to assume a role

Rule Group Setting.title: Rule Group
Rule Group Setting.name: rule_group
Rule Group Setting.tooltip: Provide an JSON object that defines the rule group rules.
Rule Group Setting.description: Provide an JSON object that defines the rule group rules.

Rules Setting.title: Rules
Rules Setting.name: rules
Rules Setting.tooltip: A string containing stateful rule group rules specifications in Suricata flat format, with one rule per line. Use this to import your existing Suricata compatible rule groups.
Rules Setting.description: A string containing stateful rule group rules specifications in Suricata flat format, with one rule per line. Use this to import your existing Suricata compatible rule groups.

parameters.title: Type
parameters.name: type
parameters.tooltip: Indicates whether the rule group is stateless or stateful. If the rule group is stateless, it contains stateless rules. If it is stateful, it contains stateful rules. Possible values are: STATELESS, STATEFUL
parameters.description: Indicates whether the rule group is stateless or stateful. If the rule group is stateless, it contains stateless rules. If it is stateful, it contains stateful rules. Possible values are: STATELESS, STATEFUL

parameters.title: Capacity
parameters.name: capacity
parameters.tooltip: The maximum operating resources that this rule group can use. Rule group capacity is fixed at creation. When you update a rule group, you are limited to this capacity. When you reference a rule group from a firewall policy, Network Firewall reserves this capacity for the rule group.
parameters.description: The maximum operating resources that this rule group can use. Rule group capacity is fixed at creation. When you update a rule group, you are limited to this capacity. When you reference a rule group from a firewall policy, Network Firewall reserves this capacity for the rule group.

parameters.title: Description
parameters.name: description
parameters.tooltip: A description of the rule group.
parameters.description: A description of the rule group.

parameters.title: Tags
parameters.name: tags
parameters.tooltip: Array of Tag objects, The key:value pairs to associate with the resource. Note Array Members: Minimum number of 1 item. Maximum number of 200 items.
parameters.description: Array of Tag objects, The key:value pairs to associate with the resource. Note Array Members: Minimum number of 1 item. Maximum number of 200 items.

operations.title: Delete Firewall
operations.description: Deletes the specified Firewall and its FirewallStatus . This operation requires the firewall's DeleteProtection flag to be FALSE. You can't revert this operation. You can check whether a firewall is in use by reviewing the route tables for the Availability Zones where you have firewall subnet mappings. Retrieve the subnet mappings by calling DescribeFirewall.

parameters.title: Type
parameters.name: Type
parameters.tooltip: Indicates whether the rule group is stateless or stateful. If the rule group is stateless, it contains stateless rules. If it is stateful, it contains stateful rules. This setting is required for requests that do not include the RuleGroupARN.
parameters.description: Indicates whether the rule group is stateless or stateful. If the rule group is stateless, it contains stateless rules. If it is stateful, it contains stateful rules. This setting is required for requests that do not include the RuleGroupARN.

operations.title: Disassociate Subnets
operations.description: Removes the specified subnet associations from the firewall. This removes the firewall endpoints from the subnets and removes any network filtering protections that the endpoints were providing.

parameters.title: Assume a Role
parameters.name: assume_role
parameters.tooltip: You must enable this option, i.e., this parameter is required, if you have specified IAM Role as the 'Configuration Type'. If you have specified Access Credentials as the 'Configuration Type', then this parameter is optional.
parameters.description: Select this option to assume a role. Note: You must enable this option, i.e., this parameter is required, if you have specified IAM Role as the 'Configuration Type'. If you have specified Access Credentials as the 'Configuration Type', then this parameter is optional. If you select this option, i.e., set it to 'True' then you must specify the following parameters:

true.title: AWS Region
true.name: aws_region
true.tooltip: AWS region of your account to access AWS Lambda.
true.description: AWS region of your account to access AWS Lambda and retrieve details of your account's limits and usage.

true.title: Role ARN

true.tooltip: ARN of the role that you want to assume to execute this action on AWS.
true.description: ARN of the role that you want to assume to execute this action on AWS.

true.title: Session Name
true.name: session_name
true.tooltip: Name of the session that will be created to execute this action on AWS.
true.description: Name of the session that will be created to execute this action on AWS.

parameters.title: Subnet IDs
parameters.name: SubnetIds
parameters.tooltip: Provide the CSV list of unique identifiers for the subnets that you want to disassociate.
parameters.description: Provide the CSV list of unique identifiers for the subnets that you want to disassociate.

parameters.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the firewall.

parameters.title: Firewall Name
parameters.name: FirewallName
parameters.tooltip: The descriptive name of the firewall. You can't change the name of a firewall after you create it.
parameters.description: The descriptive name of the firewall. You can't change the name of a firewall after you create it.

parameters.title: Update Token
parameters.name: UpdateToken
parameters.tooltip: An optional token that you can use for optimistic locking. Network Firewall returns a token to your requests that access the firewall. The token marks the state of the firewall resource at the time of the request.
parameters.description: An optional token that you can use for optimistic locking. Network Firewall returns a token to your requests that access the firewall. The token marks the state of the firewall resource at the time of the request.

parameters.title: Tags

parameters.tooltip: Array of Tag objects.
parameters.description: Array of Tag objects.

parameters.title: Next Token
parameters.name: NextToken
parameters.tooltip: When you request a list of objects with a MaxResults setting, if the number of objects that are still available for retrieval exceeds the maximum you requested, Network Firewall returns a NextToken value in the response. To retrieve the next batch of objects, use the token returned from the prior request in your next request.
parameters.description: When you request a list of objects with a MaxResults setting, if the number of objects that are still available for retrieval exceeds the maximum you requested, Network Firewall returns a NextToken value in the response. To retrieve the next batch of objects, use the token returned from the prior request in your next request.
